author: .fjl
content:
I disagree that Frame Transactions (EIP-8141) is only about a theoretical intermediate step. It changes the rules so that accounts are in charge of validating their own transactions. This means we basically never have to change the tx signature again because it completely removes the concept of signatures from the core protocol. 

To make PQ signatures viable, the protocol will move to provide building blocks such as precompiles for relevant signature algorithms.

However, you are also right in that the EOA transition still has to occur eventually. EIP-8141 does not fully solve quantum computer readiness because the existing ECDSA keys will keep working for the time being. Schemes for migrating EOAs off of ECDSA are still being designed.

author: sky.cactus
content: Share the private key for a chosen address (e.g., address 1), or a transaction signed by a chosen address.  Without one of those, it is unlikely anyone will believe you.

author: ajsutton
content: This is not the channel to discuss potential vulnerabilities. Especially wild unsubstantiated claims like this. There is an Ethereum bug bounty program for these reports: https://ethereum.org/bug-bounty/

author: username187666
content: I'm not here to fish for arguments or debates this is an all core dev channel on eth r&d server it seems like it is exactly the right channel to discuss this and look for help otherwise the tag of the channel is very misleading

author: ajsutton
content: Vulnerabilities should not be discussed in public. Use the bug bounty program.

author: ajsutton
content:
Yes I have read all your messages. You are making extraordinary claims without the skillset to actually verify them. It should come as no surprise that people are highly sceptical.  If you have a mathematical model/proof to justify your claim, submit it via the bug bounty. There is an email address listed in https://ethereum.org/bug-bounty/ for submissions.
Otherwise, please stop. You are not going to be able to have an effective discussion here and it is just going to be a distraction for others at best or publicly disclose sensitive information about a vulnerability in the worst case. Neither is acceptable behaviour in this channel.
